nodes.text: Stock Option Quotations
Table 21.2
shows near-term options on
Amazon.com
taken from the CBOE Web site (
www.cboe.com

) on May 16, 2019. Call options are listed on the left and put options on the right. Each line corresponds to a particular option. The first two digits in the option name refer to the year of expiration. The option name also includes the month of expiration and the strike or exercise price. Looking at
Table 21.2

, the first line of the left column is a call option with an exercise price of $1880 that expires on the Saturday following the third Friday of June 2019 (Saturday, June 22, 2019). The columns to the right of the name display market data for the option. The first of these columns shows the last sale price, followed by the net change from the previous day’s last reported sale price, the current bid and ask prices, and the daily volume. The final column is the
The total number of contracts of a particular option that have been written and not yet closed.
open interest
, the total number of contracts of that particular option that have been written and not yet closed.

metadata.caption: The description of each traded option can be read as: year and month of expiration, followed by the strike price. For example, the first call listed expires in June 2019 and has an exercise (strike) price of 1880.00.

config.caption: The description of each traded option can be read as: year and month of expiration, followed by the strike price. For example, the first call listed expires in June 2019 and has an exercise (strike) price of 1880.00.
config.credit: Source: Chicago Board Options Exchange at www.cboe.com.
config.activityTitle: Option Quotes for Amazon.com Stock

nodes.text: The top line of the option quote displays information about the stock itself. In this case, Amazon’s stock last traded at a price of $1903.73 per share, which is $32.58 more than where it closed the previous day (green indicates an increase).
When the exercise price of an option is equal to the current price of the stock, the option is said to be
Describes options whose exercise prices are equal to the current stock price.
at-the-money

. Notice that much of the trading occurs in options that are closest to being at-the-money—that is, calls and puts with exercise prices of $1900. Note how the June 1900 calls have high volume. They last traded for $56.90.

Stock option contracts are always written on 100 shares of stock. If, for instance, you decided to purchase one June 1880 call contract, you would be purchasing an option to buy 100 shares at $1800 per share. Option prices are quoted on a per-share basis, so the ask price of $69.20 implies that you would pay

nodes.text: for the option to sell 100 shares of Amazon’s stock for $1800 per share.
Note from
Table 21.2

that for the June 2019 expiration date, call options with lower strike prices have higher market prices—the right to buy the stock at a lower price is more valuable than the right to buy it for a higher price. Conversely, because the put option gives the holder the right to sell the stock at the strike price, puts with higher strikes are more valuable (for the same expiration date). On the other hand (not shown in the table), holding fixed the strike price, both calls and puts are more expensive for a longer time to expiration. Because these options are American-style options that can be exercised at any time, having the right to buy or sell for a longer period is valuable.
If the payoff from exercising an option immediately is positive, the option is said to be
Describes an option whose value if immediately exercised would be positive.
in-the-money
. Call options with strike prices below the current stock price are in-the-money, as are put options with strike prices above the current stock price. At the time of the quotes in
Table 21.2

, Amazon’s stock price was $1,903.73, so any call option with a strike price below $1,903.73 would be in-the-money, such as the June 1880 through 1900 calls, and any put option with a strike price above $1,903.73 would be in the money, such as the June 1905 through 1920 puts. Conversely, if the payoff from exercising the option immediately is negative, the option is
Describes an option that if exercised immediately results in a loss of money.
out-of-the-money
. Call options with strike prices above the current stock price are out-of-the-money, as are put options with strike prices below the current stock price. In
Table 21.2

, the June 1905 through June 1920 calls are out-of-the money, as are the June 1880 through 1900 puts. Of course, a holder would not exercise an out-of-the-money option. Options where the strike price and the stock price are very far apart are referred to as
Describes options that are in-the-money and for which the strike price and the stock price are very far apart.
deep in-the-money
or
Describes options that are out-of-the-money and for which the strike price and the stock price are very far apart.
deep out-of-the-money
Example 21.1 Purchasing Options
Problem

It is May 16, 2019, and you have decided to purchase 10 June call contracts on Amazon’s stock with an exercise price of $1905. Because you are buying, you must pay the ask price. How much money will this purchase cost you? Is this option in-the-money or out-of-the-money?
Solution
Plan
From
Table 21.2
, the ask price of this option is $54.75. Remember that the price quoted is per share and that each contract is for 100 shares.
Execute
You are purchasing 10 contracts and each contract is on 100 shares, so the transaction will cost

data.alt: 54.75 times 10 times 100 equals Number dollar sign 54,750

nodes.text: (ignoring any commission fees). Because this is a call option and the exercise price is above the current stock price ($1,903.73), the option is currently out-of-the-money.
Evaluate
Even though the option is currently out-of-the-money, it still has value. During the time left to expiration, the stock could rise above the exercise (strike) price of $1905.

metadata.caption: The description of each traded option can be read as: year and month of expiration, followed by the strike price. For example, the first call listed expires in June 2019 and has an exercise (strike) price of 1880.00.
